Code{4}Lib Midwest 2013 recap

Earlier this month I participated in #c4lmw, an intimate and energetic midwest regional library tech conference. The workshops were challenging and useful. Especially parsing linked data with a SPARQL server and building Jekyll. Both instances were lead by University of Kansas Medical Center librarian Jason Stirnaman and University of Iowa data services librarian Shawn Averkamp.

I gave a talk about adding a layer of local knowledge to the ecosystem of open structured data via the future of LocalWiki, and a role that libraries can play. The slides are up on slideshare, but the dynamic slides powered by Reveal.js can be found at people.lis.illinois.edu/~bzelip/c4l.

Aside from learning new tools and networking, what I appreciate most about Code{4}Lib is how open and accessible the organization is. Conference websites are malleable wikis, and the bar for involvement is interest. A major contrast with the annual ALA conference for example. I walked away from ALA 2013 in Chicago exhausted and bewildered. I walked away from #C4LMW with more skills and a sense of empowerment.
